**The American Civil War (1861‑1865) was the product of a long‑running, complex set of political, economic, social, and cultural tensions that had been building since the founding of the United States. Most historians agree that the *central* and *irreconcilable* issue was the institution of slavery, but they differ on how that issue interacted with other forces such as economics, politics, and ideas about the nature of the Union. Below is a synthesis of the major causes, the evidence that supports each, and the historiographic debates that have surrounded them.** --- ## 1. ## 1. A Concrete Excerpt from a Secession Document ### South Carolina’s “Declaration of the Immediate Causes Which Induce and Justify the Secession of South Carolina from the Federal Union” (December 20 , 1860) > “*The immediate cause of our separation is the election of a man—**Abraham Lincoln—who, by his speeches and writings, has shown himself to be hostile to the institution of slavery, and who, if elected, will… endeavor to place the slave‑holding states under the power of a majority of free‑state citizens.* > > *The people of South Carolina hold that the Constitution of the United States was established, in part, to protect the property rights of the Southern people, and that any attempt to deprive them of that property is a direct violation of the compact under which the Union was formed.*”* *(Full text available in the South Carolina Department of Archives & History, “South Carolina Declaration of Secession,” 1860.)* **Why this matters** * The declaration **places slavery front‑and‑center** as the “immediate cause” for leaving the Union. * It frames the dispute in **constitutional terms**—the South argued that the federal government had overstepped a compact that expressly protected slave property. * By invoking the **election of Lincoln**, it signals that the conflict was not merely about one politician but about the perceived future of the institution itself. --- ## 2. How Economic Differences Between North and South Fueled the Political Crisis | Dimension | Northern Economy (≈ 1860) | Southern Economy (≈ 1860) | Link to the Secession Conflict | |-----------|---------------------------|---------------------------|--------------------------------| | **Primary Production** | • Manufacturing: 45 % of U.S. industrial output.
• Diversified: textiles, iron, machinery, shipbuilding.
• Growing wage‑labor force (≈ 2.5 million workers). | • Cash‑crop agriculture: cotton (≈ 4 million bales), rice, tobacco, sugar.
• **98 % of cotton production** relied on enslaved labor.
• Small proportion of industrial activity (mainly iron foundries, limited rail‑road building). | The North’s **industrial base** thrived on free‑labor markets and protective tariffs that shielded domestic manufacturers. The South’s **plantation system** required cheap, slave‑based labor and cheap export markets for cotton. Any federal policy that altered tariffs, land‑grant colleges, or internal improvements was perceived as a threat to one region’s economic model. | | **Trade & Export Orientation** | • Export‑oriented but increasingly **domestic‑market focused** (e.g., manufactured goods sold to the South and West).
• Benefited from high tariffs that made imported British goods more expensive. | • **Export‑driven**: 60 % of U.S. exports were Southern cotton.
• Relied on **low tariffs** to keep British textile imports cheap, preserving demand for raw cotton. | The **Tariff of 1828** (“Tariff of Abominations”) and later the **Tariff of 1857** raised import duties dramatically. Southern planters argued that high tariffs reduced their export competitiveness and raised the price of imported goods they needed (machinery, clothing). Northern manufacturers welcomed the same tariffs as protection for their factories. The tariff debate became a proxy for the deeper slavery‑economy clash. | | **Infrastructure & Internal Improvements** | • Extensive rail network (≈ 9,000 mi) and a well‑developed banking system.

• Labor unions beginning to form (e.g., National Labor Union, 1866). | • **Slave labor** (≈ 4 million enslaved persons), legally treated as “property.”
